section.heading: Strategic Enforcement Plan.

para.text: On or before January 1, 2022, and January 1 of every third year thereafter, the SEA shall submit to the Council a Strategic Enforcement Plan that:
Establishes priorities;
Identifies available and needed resources while integrating the Department's enforcement functions; and
Identifies instances in which the Department can leverage the enforcement efforts of sister agencies with which the Department has adjacent, overlapping, or shared authority.
The plan required under subsection (a) of this section shall rely on existing data and industry best practices to determine enforcement priorities for the duration of the plan.
In developing the plan required under subsection (a) of this section, the SEA shall afford great weight to available complaint data and community sentiment.
For the January 1, 2026, Strategic Enforcement Plan required pursuant to subsection (a) of this section, the following information shall be included:

A description of predictive statistical models that could be used to identify properties at risk of becoming vacant or blighted, as well as the data sources and information technology infrastructure necessary to effectively implement these models;
A detailed description of proactive measures utilized by other jurisdictions in the United States to enforce vacant and blighted property registration ordinances; and
An analysis and determination of the feasibility of utilizing proactive measures to enforce the District's laws regarding registration and maintenance of vacant and blighted buildings.

For the January 1, 2027, Strategic Enforcement Plan required pursuant to subsection (a) of this section, and for the Strategic Enforcement Plans issued every 3 years thereafter, the SEA shall include a vacant and blighted property rehabilitation strategic plan. In developing the strategic plan, the SEA shall:
Analyze the extent and nature of interagency collaboration among District agencies with respect to:
Enforcing legal requirements related to vacant and blighted buildings in the District; and
Incentivizing the successful redevelopment or rehabilitation of vacant and blighted buildings;
Review the use and effectiveness of existing incentives in the District that support the redevelopment or rehabilitation of vacant and blighted buildings;
Review best practices for preventing vacancy and blight and best practices for redeveloping or rehabilitating vacant and blighted buildings;
Develop and refine performance metrics that measure the effectiveness of the District's programs, interventions, and incentives regarding vacant and blighted properties; and
Consult with stakeholders, including the following:
Advisory Neighborhood Commissions;
Organizations with significant experience redeveloping or rehabilitating vacant or blighted buildings; and
Organizations or individuals with policy or research expertise on:
Implementing strategic code enforcement programs;
Housing development incentives; and
Developing performance measures.
